message.raw:
backporting patches from STABLE branch:
- http://q12.org/pipermail/ode-cvs/2005-July/000198.html

replace dRandInt() with an all-int version.  avoids terrible performance on plats without doubles, and avoids random crashes(!) for poor D3D developers. :)

message.raw:
Replaced dRandInt implementation as suggest by [1].
This also fixes a bug encountered by [2], where dRandInt would return
a value greater than N (it should return a value between 0 and N-1).

[1] http://q12.org/pipermail/ode/2005-May/015834.html
[2] http://q12.org/pipermail/ode/2005-June/016143.html

message.raw:
Modified the configurator.c x86-64 detection routine to reflect the fact
that we are looking for an x86-64 CPU, not just a 64 bits CPU.

The define has also been changed from SYS64bits to X86_64_SYSTEM. Note
this breaks the autotool script on x86-64 systems.
message.html:
Modified the configurator.c x86-64 detection routine to reflect the fact
that we are looking for an x86-64 CPU, not just a 64 bits CPU.

The define has also been changed from SYS64bits to X86_64_SYSTEM. Note
this breaks the autotool script on x86-64 systems.

this breaks the autotool script on x86-64 systems.

message.raw:
Fixed segmentation fault that occurs in OPCODE on 64 bits systems.

Originally, OPCODE uses 32 bits integers to store pointer values. This is
a non-issue on 32 bits systems, but on 64 machines this of course causes
a nice segfault.

Changed the type used by OPCODE to store "pointer integers" from udword to
size_t. In pratice this means that 32 bits systems will use 32 bits
integers, and 64 bits systems will use 64 bits integers.
It has been suggested to use uintptr_t instead, but this type only appears
in C99 and not C++98.
message.html:

a nice segfault.

Changed the type used by OPCODE to store "pointer integers" from udword to
size_t. In pratice this means that 32 bits systems will use 32 bits
integers, and 64 bits systems will use 64 bits integers.
It has been suggested to use uintptr_t instead, but this type only appears
in C99 and not C++98.

values.message: Modified Changelog to reflect the x86-64 patch for timer.cpp.

message.raw:
Applying patch to fix timer.cpp compilation problem.

Details: timer.cpp contains inline x86 GNU assembly that is incompatible
with x86-64 assembly. This patch provides an alternative assembly path on
x86-64 machines in timer.cpp, and adds an x86-64 detection routine in
configurator.c.

Credits: original patch from Frederic Marmond
(fixed the detection routine that would detect an x86-64 enabled compiler
even on a regular x86 32 bits GCC).
message.html:
Applying patch to fix timer.cpp compilation problem.

Details: timer.cpp contains inline x86 GNU assembly that is incompatible
with x86-64 assembly. This patch provides an alternative assembly path on
x86-64 machines in timer.cpp, and adds an x86-64 detection routine in
configurator.c.

Credits: original patch from Frederic Marmond
(fixed the detection routine that would detect an x86-64 enabled compiler
even on a regular x86 32 bits GCC).

summary.raw:

Details: timer.cpp contains inline x86 GNU assembly that is incompatible
with x86-64 assembly. This patch provides an alternative assembly path on
x86-64 machines in timer.cpp, and adds an x86-64 detection routine in
configurator.c.

Credits: original patch from Frederic Marmond
(fixed the detection routine that would detect an x86-64 enabled compiler
even on a regular x86 32 bits GCC).

even on a regular x86 32 bits GCC).

only an approximation in some cases, and how.

values.message:
add a comment indicating that our new dGeomBoxPointDepth() is still
only an approximation in some cases, and how.

message.raw:
apply this code from
"John Miles" <jmiles@pop.net>:
-----------------------------------
The dGeomBoxPointDepth() function is documented to work for points both
inside and outside the box geom.  However, because the current
implementation always returns the minimum distance between the point and any
side of the box, it often returns meaningless results for input points
outside the box.

This implementation behaves identically to the current one for points inside
the box, but uses a different approximation for exterior-point distances.
The *largest* positive distance between the point and any side needs to be
returned in this case.  (Consider an exterior point that's only slightly
above the top plane of a box, but several units to the left.  The previous
implementation would have returned the distance from the point to the top
plane, which is grossly incorrect, rather than the left plane.)

Apart from any user applications that call dGeomBoxPointDepth(), the
function appears to be used only by the dTerrainY/Z contribution, as far as
I can tell.  This rewritten version (below) has been tested with dTerrainY
and seems to work fine.   It still isn't formally "right," but the
approximation it returns for exterior-point depths is at least reasonable.
-------------------------------------

The largest positive distance between the point and any side needs to be

I can tell. This rewritten version (below) has been tested with dTerrainY
and seems to work fine. It still isn't formally "right," but the

message.raw:
crasher fix from John Miles <jmiles@pop.net>:
--------------------------
Line 965 of the current version needs to be changed from

	if (ctContacts>=(iFlags & NUMC_MASK))

to

	if ((ctContacts>=(iFlags & NUMC_MASK)) || (ctContacts >=
gMaxLocalContacts))

... or memory can get trashed if more than 32 contacts are requested from
dCollide().

-- jm
